# Documentation for tests

We had to generate a floating point vector of 100 positions from a sinusoid + white noise and from the noise itself. We use this code in python:

```python
import numpy as np

import numpy as np

def generate_noisy_sine_wave():
    time = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 50)  # Create an array of time with 50 positions from 0 to 2*pi
    sine_wave = np.sin(time)  # Generate a sine wave without noise
    noise = np.random.normal(0, 0.1, 50)  # Generate an array of white noise with mean 0 and standard deviation 0.1
    
    noisy_sine_wave = sine_wave + noise  # Add the noise to the sine wave
    
    return noisy_sine_wave, noise

# Example usage of the function
noisy_sine_wave, noise = generate_noisy_sine_wave()

print("Noisy Sine Wave:")
print(noisy_sine_wave)

print("\nNoise:")
print(noise)


```

# Visualizando a resposta 

Sendo `output` a saída do código em C

```python

from matplotlib import pyplot as plt

plt.subplot(3, 1, 1)
plt.plot(noisy_sine_wave)
plt.title('Input Signal')
plt.xlabel('Samples')
plt.ylabel('Amplitude')

plt.subplot(3, 1, 2)
plt.plot(noise)
plt.title('Noise')
plt.xlabel('Samples')
plt.ylabel('Amplitude')

plt.subplot(3, 1, 3)
plt.plot(desired_output)
plt.plot(output)
plt.title('Output Signal')
plt.xlabel('Samples')
plt.ylabel('Amplitude')

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()


```
